title: Some concepts (1)
text:
Nominations commence the gas flow in the pipeline. They encompass the request for the initiation of the transportation service. They specify the receipt and delivery locations for the request.
The receiving position is the point at which gas is transferred from the upstream pipeline to the carrying pipeline. The delivery site is the point when gas is transferred from the carrying pipeline to the downstream pipeline. Nominations encompass standard transportation, stipulations for supplementary fuel, and the notion of economic cycles.









Confirmations occur among linked pipes to guarantee that gas will be transported onto the pipeline and subsequently extracted in accordance with the shipper‚Äôs nomination. The verifying parties utilize the information supplied in the nomination to reconcile the transactions that traverse the interconnect.
Scheduling involves the pipeline operator assessing the available gas flow against the required gas flow and organizing the requests in accordance with pipeline limitations. Segmentation and flow-day redirection are also addressed in Scheduling.


A Make-up is a mechanism in which shipper brings gas onto pipeline in case of ‚Äúimbalance due-pipeline‚Äù because shipper received more gas off of pipeline than it delivered onto pipeline.

title: Natural Gas Market Evolution Since December 2017
text: A structural shift began in Mexico‚Äôs natural gas industry with the implementation of market liberalization policies. This included the unbundling of transportation and marketing activities, the introduction of open access and capacity reservation mechanisms, and the gradual removal of price regulation. Since December 2017, market data has reflected persistent changes in system dynamics. Flow records, pricing trends, capacity utilization, and node behavior reveal several trends that can be classified as structural.

title: Natural Gas Market Evolution Since December 2017
text: A structural shift began in Mexico‚Äôs natural gas industry with the implementation of market liberalization policies. This included the unbundling of transportation and marketing activities, the introduction of open access and capacity reservation mechanisms, and the gradual removal of price regulation. Since December 2017, market data has reflected persistent changes in system dynamics. Flow records, pricing trends, capacity utilization, and node behavior reveal several trends that can be classified as structural.

title: Natural Gas Market Evolution Since December 2017
text:
Flow Patterns and Infrastructure Usage
One of the most relevant patterns is the sustained shift in injection behavior at northern border points, particularly interconnections with Waha. The price spread between Waha and Henry Hub, along with dispatch conditions within the SISTRANGAS system, has directly influenced daily capacity allocation and infrastructure usage.

üîπ Suggested Plot 1: Cross-border injection volumes (Waha, Agua Dulce, etc.)
Route Concentration and Operational Efficiency
CENAGAS programming reports show an increasing concentration of flows along specific corridors, while other available routes exhibit repeated underutilization. When cross-referenced with regional demand levels and contracted capacities, the data points to a reallocation of supply routes with operational implications.
üîπ Suggested Plot 3: Utilization rates by transport zone or route (stacked or line chart)
Regulatory Adjustments
Updates to tariff schemes, access criteria, and permit issuance have introduced additional market-shaping variables. However, the evidence suggests that price signals and physical availability of capacity remain the primary drivers of system behavior.
Conclusion
The ongoing changes are better explained by structural conditions than by short-term or isolated events. Continued analysis of these variables is essential to anticipate operational risks, evaluate economic efficiency, and inform regulatory adjustments grounded in actual system performance.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
Natural gas is a vital energy source for millions of homes and businesses worldwide. As a relatively clean and efficient fuel, it powers electricity generation, heats homes, maintains essential services, and fuels industries.
In 2022, U.S. power generators produced about¬†4,243 million megawatt-hours (MWh)¬†of electricity, with¬†nearly 40%¬†coming from natural gas. Similarly, in Mexico, gas-based technologies accounted for almost half of the country's¬†90,000 MW¬†of installed power capacity in 2021. Across North America and beyond, vast networks of natural gas pipelines ensure this crucial resource flows seamlessly from production fields to end users.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
section: The Backbone of Energy: Pipeline Networks
text:
The Backbone of Energy: Pipeline Networks
The natural gas pipeline system is an intricate web of steel pipes‚Äîranging from a few centimeters to several meters in diameter‚Äîthat transports gas from production sites to distribution hubs. These pipelines link supply sources‚Äîsuch as gas wells, processing plants, international interconnections, and storage facilities‚Äîto major consumption centers via¬†city gates, where local distribution begins.

The U.S.¬†boasts the world's most extensive pipeline network, spanning over¬†340,000 kilometers.
Canada¬†follows with nearly¬†61,000 km¬†of pipelines.
Mexico¬†has a significant system exceeding¬†17,000 km.

Together,¬†North America holds about 40% of the world's gas transmission pipelines, ensuring reliable energy delivery across the continent.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
From Transmission to Consumption
Gas transmission lines typically deliver fuel to¬†city gates, where local distribution networks take over, supplying residential, commercial, and industrial customers. While these distribution systems directly serve end users, the¬†real market dynamics‚Äîpricing, capacity allocation, and supply balancing‚Äîare driven by transmission pipelines.
Key¬†hubs and interconnections¬†maintain system equilibrium, ensuring gas flows efficiently across regions and over time.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
Why Pipelines Matter
Natural gas pipelines are the unsung heroes of modern life. In Mexico,¬†electricity generation without natural gas would fall short of meeting demand. Beyond power, gas fuels:

Heating & cooking¬†in homes
Industrial production¬†of glass, steel, cement, ceramics, and petrochemicals
Alternative fuel¬†for vehicles

The¬†direct link between gas availability and economic prosperity¬†is undeniable. That's why investing in¬†skilled labor, technology, and transparent operations¬†is crucial for ensuring¬†affordable, secure, and uninterrupted gas supply.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
text:
Ensuring Safe and Efficient Operations
A well-functioning pipeline system requires:

Constant monitoring¬†(leak detection, pressure checks, flow control)
Sophisticated technology¬†to manage complex injection and withdrawal points
Effective commercial coordination¬†to prevent imbalances, congestion, or underutilization

In North America, industry practices and regulations have shaped how market players interact. The¬†North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB)¬†plays a key role by defining protocols for¬†capacity management and gas scheduling. Its¬†daily gas nomination cycle‚Äîwidely adopted in the U.S. and Canada‚Äîensures seamless coordination across interconnected supply chains.

title: Natural Gas: The Lifeline of Modern Energy
section: The Need for Transparency and Accountability
text:
The Need for Transparency and Accountability
Pipelines are only as reliable as their operators.¬†Lack of competition, restricted open access, or opaque contracts¬†can disrupt affordability and supply stability‚Äîcommon challenges in transitioning gas markets like Mexico's.
To secure a stable energy future, the industry must prioritize:
‚úÖ¬†Safety
‚úÖ¬†Efficiency
‚úÖ¬†Transparency
Natural gas will remain a¬†primary energy source for decades. Public awareness, data accessibility, and regulatory progress are essential to fostering a¬†modern, responsible gas industry¬†for future generations.

title: Firm Service Contract in SISTRANGAS
text:
A¬†firm service contract¬†in natural gas transportation is a binding agreement between a pipeline operator and a user (also known as a ‚Äúshipper‚Äù). When a contract is¬†firm, the operator is obligated to transport the shipper's gas up to a¬†Maximum Daily Quantity (MDQ), regardless of demand from other users. This guarantees that the shipper can move gas up to their contracted capacity‚Äîeven during system congestion‚Äîensuring¬†uninterrupted service.
Firm service contracts also grant¬†priority access¬†in case of operational disruptions, giving these shippers an advantage over those with¬†interruptible service contracts. In essence, a firm contract secures¬†reserved pipeline capacity¬†with a high degree of reliability.

Open Access & Capacity Allocation in Mexico's SISTRANGAS
In Mexico, the¬†SISTRANGAS¬†(Integrated Natural Gas Transportation and Storage System), operated by¬†CENAGAS, has allowed shippers to reserve capacity since its first¬†open season¬†in 2017. During this process, each participating user was allocated an¬†MDQ‚Äîa contractual parameter measured in energy terms that, when managed effectively, ensures¬†flexible and continuous supply.
After the initial capacity allocation, consumers had the option to:

Become direct SISTRANGAS users¬†(entering a contract with CENAGAS).
Transfer their capacity to intermediaries¬†(gas marketers specializing in North America's complex supply logistics).

Recently,¬†CENAGAS launched a contract renewal process, ensuring service continuity for existing users and consumers.¬†Learn more here.


How Shippers & Consumers Benefit

Shippers¬†can use their reserved capacity to¬†secure supply for their own needs¬†or to serve their clients.
Consumers¬†(whether or not they act as shippers) can¬†switch suppliers freely¬†under Mexico's¬†unbundled market structure, preventing them from being captive to a single pipeline owner.

Thanks to¬†open access, firm contracts, and post-2017 renewals, end-users‚Äîhistorically dependent on¬†PEMEX's monopoly‚Äînow have direct or indirect access to pipeline routes.


Key Details on Contract Renewals

The renewal process¬†only extends or terminates¬†existing contracts‚Äîno changes¬†will be made to:

Reserved capacity (MDQ)
Primary injection/withdrawal points

However, the current¬†capacity allocation structure warrants review.



Who Holds the Capacity? A Snapshot

30 total users¬†(mostly gas marketers supplying multiple clients across SISTRANGAS).
PEMEX Transformaci√≥n Industrial (PTRI)¬†remains the¬†dominant shipper, despite market liberalization.
Some large consumers (e.g.,¬†Braskem Idesa) manage their own transportation contracts.



Regionalization & Contract Distribution

SISTRANGAS can be divided into¬†tariff zones¬†(based on 2015 classifications).
Each shipper's¬†injection/withdrawal nodes¬†indicate their market reach.
45 active contracts¬†(color-coded below), mostly held by¬†PEMEX and CFE.



Contracted Capacities: Who Leads?

The largest firm capacity (6.8 Bcf/day total) is held under¬†contract SBF/002/16‚Äîbelonging to¬†PEMEX TRI.
Only¬†6.3 Bcf/day¬†was allocated via open season, suggesting¬†CENAGAS has awarded additional firm capacity outside standard procedures.



Contract Expirations: What's Next?
Most active contracts¬†expire by mid-2023, with very few long-term agreements in place. This raises questions about¬†future capacity allocation strategies.


Final Insight
While Mexico's gas market has progressed since 2014,¬†PEMEX still dominates. The renewal process will shape whether new players gain more influence‚Äîor if legacy shippers maintain control.
